IRM 4.23.15.1. Deleted Overview. New subsection, Program Scope and Objectives. Rearranged existing IRM content to place information involving internal controls for a program IRM under this subsection to conform to the new rules to ensure that the program’s internal controls are adequately expressed in the IRM.
IRM 4.23.15.1.1. New subsection, Background. Formerly IRM 4.23.15.1, Overview.
IRM 4.23.15.1.5. New subsection, Program Reports, provides information on the reporting of objectives and reports submitted to the Director, Specialty Examination Policy.
Editorial updates have been made throughout this section.
This transmittal supersedes IRM 4.23.15, dated February 7,
This section contains instructions and guidelines for all LB&I, TE/GE, and SB/SE employees when employment tax issues.
Table of Contents
From the Office of Chief Counsel

) Purpose: This section explains the steps to take when seeking technical advice from the Office of Chief Counsel. Requesting technical advice is priate when the application of the law to the facts involved is unclear. (

) Audience: This section contains instructions and guidelines for all Large Business & International (LB&I), Tax Exempt/Government Entities (TE/GE), and Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) employees dealing with employ- ment tax issues. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Specialty Examination Policy of SB/SE. (
) Program Owner: Program Manager - Employment Tax Policy. The mission Employment Tax Policy is to establish effective policies and procedures and support compliance with employment tax laws. (

) Primary Stakeholders: • Employment Tax – Workload Selection and Delivery :S:ETEGCS:EWSD) • Specialty Examination - Employment Tax (SE:S:E:SE:ET) • Specialty Examination Policy, Employment Tax Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:S- P:ET) • Other areas that are affected by these policies and procedures Appeals, Counsel, SB/SE Examination, LB&I, and TE/GE. (

) Technical questions arising in employment tax cases involving the tion and application of tax laws, regulations, or other precedent published by the Department of Treasury to a speciﬁc set of facts should be referred to Office of Chief Counsel. A request for technical advice must include the the issues for which technical advice is requested, the applicable law, and Service’s and taxpayer’s position. (

) Deﬁnitions of terms and the procedures for furnishing technical advice to Directors and Appeals, in areas under the jurisdiction of the Associates Counsel, are found in the second Revenue Procedure that is published annually. This revenue procedure is the controlling document to use in the preparation, submission, and disposition of requests for technical advice. revenue procedure, revised yearly, can be found as Rev. Proc.
XX-
representing the current year.) (

) Before requesting technical advice, there must be a request for assistance a recommendation from TEGE Division Counsel (TEGEDC). Any with that recommendation must be resolved through their respective sors. See the current year Rev. Proc.
XX-
for additional guidance. (
) In some employment tax inquiries, TEGEDC may handle the technical issue, thus negating the need for Associate Chief Counsel involvement. (
) Form SS–

, Determination of Worker Status for Purposes of Federal ment Taxes and Income Tax Withholding, may be used when supplying information on employer-employee relationship questions. See IRM Supplemental Procedures for Contacting Workers, for additional information. (

) In general, a ﬁeld office may request technical advice from the appropriate Associate Chief Counsel office on any technical or procedural question arises during an examination. Likewise, the taxpayer may also request Internal Revenue Manual

technical advice during the examination. Advice should be requested in in which any of the following conditions exist:

in which any of the following conditions exist: a. The law and regulations are not clear on the issue being considered there is no published precedent for determining the proper treatment the issue. b. There is reason to believe that a lack of uniformity in the treatment of issue exists. c. A doubtful or contentious issue is involved in a number of cases. d. The issue is very unusual or complex and warrants associate office sideration. e. The ﬁeld office believes that securing technical advice from the office is in the best interest of the Service. (
) When there is doubt as to whether or not a case should be submitted for technical advice, such doubt should be resolved in favor of requesting technical advice. (
) Employment tax provisions are found at Internal Revenue Code Subtitle C: • Chapter
, Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA), • Chapter
, Railroad Retirement Tax Act (RRTA), • Chapter
, Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA), • Chapter
, Federal Income Tax Withholding (FITW), and • Chapter
, General Provisions relating to employment taxes and lection of income taxes at source. (
) The Employment Tax Program is governed by Policy Statements and other internal guidance that apply to all Service personnel regardless of division. The Policy Statements found in IRM

, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policies of the Internal Revenue Service apply to all tax issues and examinations. Examiners should review these Policy State- ments to properly perform their examination duties. (

) A website, Delegation Orders by Process, located at https://www.irs.gov/ privacy-disclosure/delegation-orders-and-policy-statements-by-process, marizes data contained in the applicable IRM sections under IRM
, to Delegation Orders, in a single, electronic source. (
) IRM
provides Servicewide instructions for all operating divisions with employees involved with the correct ﬁling, reporting, and payment of ment taxes. IRM

serves as the foundation for consistent employment taxes by various IRS operating divisions. By providing one of authority for all operating divisions, the Service greatly reduces and procedural inconsistencies. (
) Director, Specialty Examination Policy is responsible for the procedures updates addressed in this IRM. (
) Director, Specialty Examination is the executive responsible for operational compliance.

From the Office of Chief Counsel
page (
) Employment tax examiners should consider the disclosure provisions when preparing agreed and unagreed case reports. See the Disclosure web site at: for additional information. (

) The Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS whose employees assist taxpayers experiencing economic harm, are seeking help in resolving tax problems that have not been resolved through normal procedures, or who believe that an IRS system or procedure not working as it should. Pub

, “Taxpayer Advocate Service - We Are to Help You”, provides contact and additional information. The program is designed to alleviate taxpayer hardships that arise from systemic problems or the application of the Internal Revenue Code. In addition, see IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria, and IRM
, TAS tions Assistance Request (OAR) Process, for additional information. (
) Rev. Proc.
XX-
, Section

- “Initiating a Request for Technical Advice,” provides that, before requesting a technical advice memorandum (TAM), the — ﬁeld office must request assistance and a recommendation from ﬁeld If the ﬁeld office disagrees with that recommendation, the ﬁeld office must reconciliation with ﬁeld counsel through their respective supervisors. Any request for technical advice must be approved in writing by the Director. A office or the taxpayer may request a TAM. (

) During an examination, the taxpayer or his/her representative may request an issue be referred to the Associate Chief Counsel office for technical on the grounds of lack of uniformity or that the issue is so unusual or as to warrant consideration by Associate Chief Counsel office. (See Policy Statement
at IRM
) Generally, requests for technical advice are submitted to the Associate Chief Counsel office on Form

, Request Technical Advice Memorandum, including requests for technical advice on employee plans, exempt organizations, and governmental entities. a. If the examiner thinks that a taxpayer’s request for referral of an issue the Associate Chief Counsel office for technical advice does not warrant consideration, the examiner will advise the taxpayer. The taxpayer may appeal the decision not to request technical advice by submitting to the examiner within thirty calendar days a statement of the facts, law and arguments on the issue, and the reasons why the matter should be referred to the Associate Chief Counsel office for technical advice. A request by the taxpayer for an extension beyond the thirty-day period must be in writing and be approved by the examiner’s ﬁrst and second level manager. b. The examiner will submit the taxpayer’s appeal to the manager, along with a written statement of why the issue should not be referred to the Associate Chief Counsel office. The manager will determine on the of the statement whether technical advice will be requested. If the manager denies the taxpayer’s request, the taxpayer will be notiﬁed in writing of the reasons for the denial. c. The taxpayer may not appeal the decision of the manager. However, proposed denial is subject to review. d. If the taxpayer does not agree with the proposed denial, all data on the issue for which technical advice has been sought, including the taxpay- er’s written request and statements, will be submitted to the appropriate Director as deﬁned in Section
- “Deﬁnitions”, of the current year Rev. Internal Revenue Manual

) Generally, requests for technical advice are submitted to the Associate Chief Counsel office on Form
, Request for Technical Advice Memorandum, including requests for technical advice on employee plans, exempt organizations, and governmental entities.

a. If the examiner thinks that a taxpayer’s request for referral of an issue the Associate Chief Counsel office for technical advice does not warrant consideration, the examiner will advise the taxpayer. The taxpayer may appeal the decision not to request technical advice by submitting to the examiner within thirty calendar days a statement of the facts, law and arguments on the issue, and the reasons why the matter should be referred to the Associate Chief Counsel office for technical advice. A request by the taxpayer for an extension beyond the thirty-day period must be in writing and be approved by the examiner’s ﬁrst and second level manager. b. The examiner will submit the taxpayer’s appeal to the manager, along with a written statement of why the issue should not be referred to the Associate Chief Counsel office. The manager will determine on the of the statement whether technical advice will be requested. If the manager denies the taxpayer’s request, the taxpayer will be notiﬁed in writing of the reasons for the denial. c. The taxpayer may not appeal the decision of the manager. However, proposed denial is subject to review. d. If the taxpayer does not agree with the proposed denial, all data on the issue for which technical advice has been sought, including the taxpay- er’s written request and statements, will be submitted to the appropriate Director as deﬁned in Section
- “Deﬁnitions”, of the current year Rev.
Proc.
XX-

, for review of the proposed denial. The person for review may consult with the Associate office, if appropriate. e. While the proposed denial package is being reviewed, the ﬁeld office suspend action on the issue (except when the delay would prejudice Government’s interest) until it is notiﬁed that the proposed denial is approved or disapproved. This notiﬁcation is generally made within

calendar days after receipt of the data. The review will be based solely on the written materials submitted by the taxpayer and the ﬁeld office. conference will be held in Associate Chief Counsel office in regard to appeal of a denial at this level. (
) Rev. Proc.
XX-
, Section

, “Pre-submission Conferences,” describes the pre-submission process. A pre-submission conference is mandatory. The parties should discuss the framing of the issues, the background information, and documents that should be included in the request for technical advice. taxpayer and representatives from the ﬁeld office, ﬁeld counsel, and the Associate office may attend the pre-submission conference. If a request for technical advice is submitted without ﬁrst holding a pre-submission the Associate office will return the request for advice. Requests for technical advice can proceed even if a taxpayer declines to participate in a pre- submission conference. (

) Before requesting a pre-submission conference, the ﬁeld office and the taxpayer must exchange proposed statements of the pertinent facts and issues. A request for a pre-submission conference must be submitted in by the ﬁeld office with the assistance of ﬁeld counsel. The request should identify the Associate office expected to have jurisdiction over the request for TAM and should include a brief explanation of the primary issue. (
) See Revenue Procedure
XX-

(issued annually) for procedure on transmit- ting pre-submission materials. Generally, the pre-submission materials are from the ﬁeld office to ﬁeld counsel for the ﬁeld counsel to submit to the Associate office. (

) Every request for technical advice must include a memorandum that the facts, issues, applicable law, and argument supporting the taxpayer’s position on the issues and the ﬁeld office’s position on the issues. The ﬁeld office will prepare this statement with the assistance of ﬁeld counsel. If the taxpayer and the ﬁeld office disagree about ultimate ﬁndings of facts or about the relevance of facts, all of the facts should be included with an explanation that highlights the areas of disagreement. The ﬁeld office submits the request for technical advice. For a complete set of instructions, see the current year Rev. Proc.
XX-
, Section
, “Submitting the Request for Technical Advice.” (
) Form

is transmitted electronically to the IRS. See form instructions for complete details. For SB/SE Employment Tax, an information copy should be sent to the SB/SE Director, Specialty Examination Policy. If the request an LB&I case, the phrase “Controlled LB&I Case” should be included in the subject heading to ensure that the request receives the highest possible priority at all levels. (
) It is the responsibility of the ﬁeld office or Specialty Operation to determine whether technical advice will be requested on any issue. Each request must

This notiﬁcation is generally made within

calendar days after receipt of the data. The review will be based solely on the written materials submitted by the taxpayer and the ﬁeld office. No conference will be held in Associate Chief Counsel office in regard to the appeal of a denial at this level.

is transmitted electronically to the IRS. See form instructions for complete details. For SB/SE Employment Tax, an information copy should be sent to the SB/SE Director, Specialty Examination Policy. It is the responsibility of the ﬁeld office or Specialty Operation to determine whether technical advice will be requested on any issue. Each request must be
Advice From the Office of Chief Counsel 4.23.15 page
submitted through proper channels and be signed by the Director or delegate and should include, in writing, the arguments submitted by the area in support of its position on the issue or issues. (
) Each request for technical advice should state the name and address of the taxpayer’s authorized representative (if any), and whether a power of attorney is on ﬁle. (

) To facilitate necessary personal contact between the ﬁeld office and Associate Chief Counsel office on pending technical advice cases, the following proce- dures are provided: a. The name and telephone number of the examination group manager examiner will be provided on Form

For SB/SE Employment Tax requests, the referral will be coordinated with the assigned program analyst on the SB/SE Employment Tax Policy staff. b. Upon receipt of a request for technical advice, a branch representative from the Associate Chief Counsel office with primary responsibility for request will contact the ﬁeld office to acknowledge receipt. (

) When technical advice is requested by the Service, the taxpayer must be informed and furnished a copy of the request. The taxpayer will be given ﬁve calendar days to indicate, in writing, any disagreement about facts and questions. A request for additional time from the taxpayer must be in writing and be approved by the ﬁrst and second level manager who have jurisdiction. Every effort should be made to reach agreement on the facts and speciﬁc points at issue. After the ﬁve-day period or extension has expired, the request for technical advice will be forwarded with the taxpayer’s statement, if to Office of Chief Counsel to the attention of the Associate Area Counsel. Note: The above does not apply in cases involving civil or criminal fraud investiga- tions and jeopardy or termination assessments.
submitted through proper channels and be signed by the Director or delegate and should include, in writing, the arguments submitted by the area in support of its position on the issue or issues.
The name and telephone number of the examination group manager and examiner will be provided on Form

When technical advice is requested by the Service, the taxpayer must be informed and furnished a copy of the request. The taxpayer will be given ﬁve calendar days to indicate, in writing, any disagreement about facts and speciﬁc questions. A request for additional time from the taxpayer must be in writing and be approved by the ﬁrst and second level manager who have jurisdiction. Every effort should be made to reach agreement on the facts and speciﬁc points at issue. After the ﬁve

day period or extension has expired, the request for technical advice will be forwarded with the taxpayer’s statement, if received, to Office of Chief Counsel to the attention of the Associate Area Counsel.

When technical advice is requested by the Service, the taxpayer must be informed and furnished a copy of the request. The taxpayer will be given ﬁve calendar days to indicate, in writing, any disagreement about facts and speciﬁc questions. A request for additional time from the taxpayer must be in writing and be approved by the ﬁrst and second level manager who have jurisdiction. Every effort should be made to reach agreement on the facts and speciﬁc points at issue. After the ﬁve-day period or extension has expired, the request for technical advice will be forwarded with the taxpayer’s statement, if to Office of Chief Counsel to the attention of the Associate Area Counsel.
Note: The above does not apply in cases involving civil or criminal fraud investiga- tions and jeopardy or termination assessments.

) If the taxpayer initiates the action to request technical advice and the taxpay- er’s statement of the facts and points at issue are not acceptable to the ﬁeld office, the examiner will advise the taxpayer, in writing, of the areas of dis- agreement. The taxpayer will then have ten calendar days after receiving the written notice to reply. If an extension beyond the ten calendar days is requested, in writing, it must be approved by either the territory manager or the Area Director of Appeals. If agreement cannot be reached, both the statements of the taxpayer and the examiner will be forwarded to the Office of Chief Counsel with the request for technical advice. (
) Usually within

calendar days after the technical branch at the Associate Chief Counsel office receives the request for technical advice, an attorney will telephone the Area Office, or appropriate government entities approving official, to discuss the procedural and substantive issues in the request. Area managers are encouraged to telephone the branch representative to discuss the progress of the case. (

) The Associate Chief Counsel office will indicate whether additional information is needed and will obtain that information from the taxpayer or ﬁeld office in the most expeditious manner possible. Any additional information from the taxpayer must be provided within
calendar days of the request, unless an extension of time is requested from the Associate Chief Counsel office in
writing and the request is approved. The additional information must be sent the Associate Chief Counsel office, and the taxpayer must also send a copy the Director for comment. (

) Every request for technical advice must include a statement of proposed deletions from public inspection. Because the text of a technical advice memoranda, TAM, is open to public inspection, the taxpayer must provide a statement indicating any desired deletions. A taxpayer who wants only addresses, and identifying numbers deleted must explicitly state these tions in the deletion statement. The deletion statement appears in a document from the memo. A stamped signature or faxed signature is not permitted. If the deletion statement is not received within

calendar days after the taxpayer is notiﬁed a deletion statement must be provided, the ﬁeld office will provide the Associate office with an appropriate deletion For additional information on the deletion statement, see the current year Proc.
XX-
, Section

) The ﬁeld office prepares the memo requesting technical advice with the tance of ﬁeld counsel and sends it to the taxpayer by mail or by fax. The taxpayer has ﬁve calendar days from the date of mailing or faxing to by providing a written statement specifying any disagreement on the facts issues. After the taxpayer’s response is received by the ﬁeld office, the will have

calendar days to resolve remaining disagreements. If all ments about the statement of facts and issues are resolved, the ﬁeld office prepare a single statement of those agreed facts and issue. If continue, both the taxpayer’s set of facts and issues and the ﬁeld’s set of and issues will be forwarded to the Associate office. The ﬁeld office, with the assistance of ﬁeld counsel, will prepare a memorandum to the Associate highlighting the material factual differences, and provide a copy to the This memo will be forwarded with the initial request for technical advice. The taxpayer’s statement of facts and issues must be accompanied by the declaration:

Every request for technical advice must include a statement of proposed deletions from public inspection. Because the text of a technical advice memoranda, TAM, is open to public inspection, the taxpayer must provide a statement indicating any desired deletions. A taxpayer who wants only names, addresses, and identifying numbers deleted must explicitly state these condi- tions in the deletion statement. The deletion statement appears in a separate document from the memo. A stamped signature or faxed signature is not permitted. If the deletion statement is not received within

calendar days after the taxpayer is notiﬁed a deletion statement must be provided, the ﬁeld office will provide the Associate office with an appropriate deletion statement. For additional information on the deletion statement, see the current year Rev. Proc.
XX-
, Section

tance of ﬁeld counsel and sends it to the taxpayer by mail or by fax. The taxpayer has ﬁve calendar days from the date of mailing or faxing to respond by providing a written statement specifying any disagreement on the facts and issues. After the taxpayer’s response is received by the ﬁeld office, the parties will have 10 calendar days to resolve remaining disagreements. If all disagree- ments about the statement of facts and issues are resolved, the ﬁeld office will prepare a single statement of those agreed facts and issue. If disagreements continue, both the taxpayer’s set of facts and issues and the ﬁeld’s set of facts and issues will be forwarded to the Associate office. The ﬁeld office, with the assistance of ﬁeld counsel, will prepare a memorandum to the Associate office highlighting the material factual differences, and provide a copy to the This memo will be forwarded with the initial request for technical advice. The taxpayer’s statement of facts and issues must be accompanied by the

“Under penalties of perjury, I declare that I have examined this information, including accompanying documents, and, to the best of my knowledge and belief, the information contains all relevant facts relating to the request for technical advice, and such facts are true, correct, and complete.”
This declaration must be signed in accordance with the requirements in section 7.015 (b) of the current year Rev. Proc. 20XX-1.

(b) of the current year Rev. Proc.
XX-

The ﬁeld office will offer the taxpayer an opportunity to participate in the devel- opment of the TAM. If the taxpayer does not participate in a material stage of the process after being offered an opportunity, the Associate office will none- theless process the request, and the taxpayer will have waived the right to participate in the development and issuance of the TAM, including the right to have a conference if the proposed TAM is adverse to the taxpayer. (See the current year Rev. Proc.
XX-
, Section

, “Taxpayer Conferences”.) If the TAM relates to a SB/SE or TE/GE taxpayer, the ﬁeld office must send one paper copy to the Division Counsel of the operating division that has juris- diction over the taxpayer’s tax return. If the TAM relates to an LB&I taxpayer,
Advice From the Office of Chief Counsel
) When an employment tax case requires coordination with Headquarters Counsel, there is sometimes a period of inactivity while the examiner is Code “
” for guidance to be provided or review of unagreed write ups to be Tax During such periods of inactivity, status code “

” is available for use by for ployment tax examiners to suspend a case if: or • There is no other work that can be completed pending receipt of guidance, and • The examiner expects the inactivity to continue for a period greater
days. (
) When use of the suspense status code is appropriate, the examiner will: • Update the case to status code “
” using local group procedures, • Follow up monthly with the National Office of Counsel contact, and • Document these actions in the case ﬁle. (
) No time should be charged to the case while in status code “
”. If audit work can be completed while waiting for a response from National or Counsel, the case must remain in status code “
